Eugene,

I don't organize my tests with one test class per model class. Ins=
tead, I have one test class per fixture. For example, if I wanted to test w=
ith both empty lists and lists with elements, I would have two classes:

cl=
ass EmptyListTest {
  List<String> list;
  @Before public void initialize()=
 {
    list=3D new ArrayList<String>();
  }
  ...
}

class PopulatedListTes=
t {
  List<String> list;
  @Before public void initialize() {
    list=3D n=
ew ArrayList<String>();
    list.add("one");
    list.add("two");
  }
  ...=

}

Following this style, different test methods in a single parameterized =
test class will all share the same parameters.

The JUnit tests are not cur=
rently organized very well with respect to this principle. I find that when=
 I am in a hurry to write the next test I tend to put it in the same test c=
lass as the last test. I need to 1) re-organize the JUnit tests and 2) slow=
 down a little.

I always err on the side of running too many tests, so I d=
on't find it hugely annoying to run all the tests related to a change even =
when I have multiple test classes per model class.

Sincerely yours,

Kent =
Beck
